question: What product forms when prehistoric animals die and their soft parts decay?

content.source_1: Fossil fuels form over millions of years from the buried, decayed remains of ancient organisms subjected to heat and pressure.
content.source_2: Petroleum is a fossil fuel generated chiefly from the organic matter of ancient marine microorganisms (including zooplankton) that died, decayed, and were buried under sediments.
content.source_3: In marine environments, when animals die, their soft tissues typically decay rapidly, while their calcium-carbonate shells or skeletons can remain.
content.source_4: Thick accumulations of shells and skeletal fragments on the seafloor can compact and cement into limestone.
content.source_5: Coal is derived mainly from terrestrial plant material rather than from animal remains.
content.source_6: Zooplankton are animals and constitute a major fraction of the marine organic matter that becomes petroleum source rock.
